wikipedia_page.main: Sir Edward Wingfield KCB (6 March 1834 – 5 March 1910), was a British barrister and civil servant who held the position of Permanent Under-Secretary of State for the Colonies from 1897 to 1900.

link_mentions.page: Under-Secretary of State for the Colonies

response: The village was formerly the location of Tickencote Hall, built in 1705 and demolished in 1950. This was the seat of the Wingfield family who carried out much of the restoration of the church. Notable family members included the civil servant Sir Edward Wingfield; Maurice Edward Wingfield CMG, son of John Wingfield, acting Colonial Secretary of the Colony of the Gambia; and Major John Maurice Wingfield (brother of Maurice Edward Wingfield), who became High Sheriff of Rutland in 1911.
* Sir Edward Wingfield of Kimbolton (died 1603), English politician
* Edward Wingfield, 2nd Viscount Powerscourt (1729–1764), Irish politician
* Sir Edward Wingfield (civil servant) (1834–1910), British civil servant
* Sir Edward Wingfield, a retired civil servant, lived at Mulbarton Hall in the early 1900s.
*Edward Wingfield, Assistant Under-Secretary of State, Colonial Office.
* Edward Wingfield, Permanent Under-Secretary of State for the Colonies
Sheringham died in Gloucester in 1904. He was the father-in-law of the civil servant Sir Edward Wingfield.
*Sir Edward Wingfield and his wife Mary Georgina
